prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For our frequency set-up we will use the standard single continuum, centred at 336.5GHz. Our science goals are centred around continuum detections and we adopt a single frequency set-up for all targets.
We do not require resolved imaging and therefore 1.2 resolution is sufficient for our science goals.

The aim of this science goal is to obtain band-7 (870um) observations of z=1.5-2.0 FIR undetected radio-loud AGN in COSMOS at a 1 sigma sensitivity limit of 0.09 mJy. Based on previous cycle 1 and cycle 2 observations of similar sensitivities, as well as extensive SED fitting of these sources with fake ALMA photometry, we find that this sensitivity is necessary to achieve the science objectives of this proposal. With observations of this sensitivity we will be able to place stronger constraints on the SFRs of these sources compared to what is currently achieved with Herschel observations, allowing us construct detailed SFR and sSFR distributions of the overall sample.

For our frequency set-up we will use the standard single continuum, centred at 336.5GHz. Our science goals are centred around continuum detections and we adopt a single frequency set-up for all targets.
We do not require resolved imaging and therefore 1.2 resolution is sufficient for our science goals.

The aim of this science goal is to obtain band-7 (870um) observations of z=2.0-2.5 FIR undetected radio-loud AGN in COSMOS at a 1 sigma sensitivity limit of 0.09 mJy. Based on previous cycle 1 and cycle 2 observations of similar sensitivities, as well as extensive SED fitting of these sources with fake ALMA photometry, we find that this sensitivity is necessary to achieve the science objectives of this proposal. With observations of this sensitivity we will be able to place stronger constraints on the SFRs of these sources compared to what is currently achieved with Herschel observations, allowing us construct detailed SFR and sSFR distributions of the overall sample.

For our frequency set-up we will use the standard single continuum, centred at 336.5GHz. Our science goals are centred around continuum detections and we adopt a single frequency set-up for all targets.
We do not require resolved imaging and therefore 1.2 resolution is sufficient for our science goals.

The aim of this science goal is to obtain band-7 (870um) observations of z=2.5-3.2 FIR undetected radio-loud AGN in COSMOS at a 1 sigma sensitivity limit of 0.09 mJy. Based on previous cycle 1 and cycle 2 observations of similar sensitivities, as well as extensive SED fitting of these sources with fake ALMA photometry, we find that this sensitivity is necessary to achieve the science objectives of this proposal. With observations of this sensitivity we will be able to place stronger constraints on the SFRs of these sources compared to what is currently achieved with Herschel observations, allowing us construct detailed SFR and sSFR distributions of the overall sample.

For our frequency set-up we will use the standard single continuum, centred at 336.5GHz. Our science goals are centred around continuum detections and we adopt a single frequency set-up for all targets.
We do not require resolved imaging and therefore 1.2 resolution is sufficient for our science goals.

The aim of this science goal is to obtain band-7 (870um) observations of z=1.5-3.2 FIR detected radio-loud AGN in COSMOS at a 1 sigma sensitivity limit of 0.2 mJy. On the basis of extensive SED fitting of these sources to combined MIR and FIR photometry we believe that this sensitivity is a good compromise between achieving significant detections at 870um and low exposure times. With observations of this sensitivity we will be able to place stronger constraints on the SFRs of these sources compared to what is currently achieved with Herschel observations, allowing us construct detailed SFR and sSFR distributions of the overall sample.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the oustanding issues in the formation and evolution of galaxies is a definitive measurement of the impact that AGN have on Star Formation (SF). In the local Universe there is clear evidence that radio-luminous AGN (RLAGN) suppress SF in massive galaxies. However, in the distant Universe the picture is more mixed, with reports for RLAGN suppressing, enhancing, or having no impact on SF! A major issue is the lack of sufficiently deep FIR-submm observations to measure the SF properties of a sample of typical distant RLAGN. The primary aim of this proposal is to build on our earlier ALMA programme of X-ray selected radio-normal AGN and measure individual SF rates (SFRs) for a complete sample of RLAGN over the same key range in redshift as our radio-normal AGN (z=1.5-3.2). With the proposed observations we will directly compare SFR and specific SFR (SFR per unit mass) distributions of RLAGN, radio-normal AGN, and SF galaxies to search for evidence of suppressed or enhanced SF in the hosts of the RLAGN. We will also explore claims that extended RLAGN have lower SFRs when compared to compact RLAGN, testing whether the extended RLAGN have suppressed the SF in the host galaxy.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Sheffield, University of
